newsitem.title: INDIA: India tax crackdown seen making little headway.
newsitem.headline: India tax crackdown seen making little headway.

text.p: India's tax evasion crackdown promised by Finance Minister P. Chidambaram is unlikely to help the government make much headway in its efforts to rein in a high fiscal deficit, economic analysts said on Sunday.
They said the answer to bridging high deficits was curbing government expenditure, improving efficiency of state-run companies and making more self- employed people pay taxes.
"Tax evaders must be severely dealt with and they will be punished," Chidambaram told parliament on Friday in reply to a debate on the federal budget for 1996/97 (April-March).
"We will become more and more strict," he said.
Mrityunjoy Athreya, a leading management consultant, told Reuters: "That (a crackdown) upsets business confidence. Tax raids frighten the honest and do not scare the dishonest."
Officials say India has to curb its fiscal deficit and inflation, but must raise funds to build infrastructure facilities needed for high economic growth.
India is aiming for 6.6 percent growth in 1996/97, compared with 7.0 percent the previous year.

Chidambaram, who unveiled in July the first budget of Indian's centre-left coalition government, said it was the turn of taxpayers to respond after a steady easing of tax rates since 1991, when India launched its economic reform programme.
"It is not a fully valid argument," Athreya said. "I think tax rates in India are still high."
Analysts say customs duties have been cut but individual tax rates are still high, starting at 20 percent on individuals with annual incomes as low as 40,000 rupees ($1,142).
Corporate tax, now 46 percent, should be cut to 30 percent, Athreya said.
Officials say inflation based on wholesale prices is around 5.0 percent after spending most of the past five years at around 10 percent. But a high fiscal deficit could push prices up again.
"It is true that tax compliance is weak," former central bank governor R.N. Malhtotra told Reuters. But he said this alone was not enough.
"The fiscal deficit is ultimately a balance between revenue and expenditure. I think it is necessary to tackle both," he said.
Despite talk of a vast middle class market, estimated at between 200 and 400 million in a population of 930 million, the number of taxpayers at 10 million is far too low, analysts say.
Potential taxpayers, including the self-employed such as transport operators and affluent farmers are not taxed, they say.
"A large number of people who are eligible for taxation are not paying taxes," Malhotra said.
While commodity taxes have been lowered, India must move further towards value- added taxation, now implemented only in a few industries, for effective taxation, Athreya said.

Chidambaram showed a resolve to widen the tax net in July when his budget imposed a controversial minimum tax on companies that earlier had avoided taxation by using a law that permitted exemption on profits if they were ploughed back as investment.
India's tax-to-GDP ratio is expected to rise to 10.5 percent this fiscal year, up from 10.1 percent in 1995/96, Chidambaram said on Friday. He said it must rise further.

The finance ministry wants to cut the fiscal deficit -- or budget deficit plus net government borrowings -- to 5.0 percent of GDP in 1996/97 from 5.9 percent the previous year. It aims to reduce it eventually to 4.0 percent but has given no time frame.
